title: How Wealth Managers are Attracting the Ultra Rich
text:
Text size

Wealth managers in the U.S. have been strengthening their staffs and family office service offerings to attract, and keep, the most well-to-do investors in the country.

Firms ranging from UBS Global Wealth Management and Bank of America Private Bank, to smaller institutions such as U.S. Bank’s Ascent Private Capital Management and Wilmington Trust, are beefing up staff and services to focus attention on serving the country’s wealthiest.

Newer entrants are rapidly gaining assets in this ultra-wealth sector, too, by offering specialized services. Cresset Asset Management, for instance, focuses on private and direct investments for its clients, and offers their employees—and even clients—an ownership stake in the firm, according to Michael Cole, Cresset’s CEO.

A key reason banks are interested in managing money for the ultra rich is profit. In a Credit Suisse presentation last year, the bank said the wealth management business for ultra-high-net-worth clients generates returns on investment of more than 30%, compared to returns of greater than 15% for high-net-worth clients and returns in the range of 10% to 15% for the affluent, according to Johann Scholtz, an equity analyst at Morningstar.

The number of ultra wealthy—those with at least US$30 million in investable assets—rose by 9.5% in North America to 90,440 in 2017, according to Wealth-X’s latest report on the sector. Combined, these individuals hold at least $11 trillion in wealth.

“It’s a question of scale,” Scholtz says. “Portfolios are bigger, and [wealth managers] are able to sell more complex and more bespoke products to that group—which you can’t do with other clients—and the [client] churn rate is much lower.”

In other words, investors with more complex needs are less likely to switch between different banks.

Banks also are leaning more on their wealth management businesses because they provide a “revenue stream that’s not related to the interest-rate cycle,” Scholtz says. But, he adds, not all banks can jump into this business because they can’t offer the services that the ultra-wealthy require. “The barriers to entry are much lower at the bottom of the wealth pyramid.”

UBS Creates Family Office Solutions Group

For UBS Global Wealth Management, the “ultra-high-net worth business in the United States has been the fastest growing business that we have,” says John Mathews, head of the firm’s ultra practice.

Mathews expects this growth will continue, particularly as aging Baby Boomer business owners sell their companies, potentially reaping hundreds of millions. These aren’t necessarily the country’s next billionaires, but “it’s the family that sells a pipe-fitting company in Louisiana for $325 million,” he says. “It’s actually an underserved market.”

Billionaires whose wealth already is managed through a well-staffed institutional family office are covered by UBS’s global family office group, which can provide the “institutional connectivity,” these investors need for electronic trading, global custody, or leveraged lending.

But to serve the growing wealth tier below that—those with at least US$100 million—UBS in January created what it calls the “family office solutions group.” The goal is to provide the kind of customized, comprehensive advice and services that wealthy individuals require without having to set up their own personal family office.

While UBS has offered similar expertise and services to its wealthiest clients in the past, this new effort puts 20 product specialists and experts in topics like philanthropy in one group that the firm’s financial advisors can tap. Aside from advisory services (like trust and estates) and transaction services (like lending or alternative investments), the group can take care of administrative tasks for families, such as consolidating reporting, and concierge services.

“We can either act as the family office to the client or we can be the family office to their family office,” Mathews says.

A Nimble Competitor

Cresset Asset Management, which was formed two years ago by private-equity firm founders Avy Stein and Eric Becker, is aiming to fill this wealth niche, too, although focusing on providing family office services to those with a net worth of at least $10 million, says CEO Cole, formerly head of Ascent.

“Clients are going from entrepreneurs to what I call capital-preneurs—their business is becoming the business of capital, and they’re not experienced in doing that,” Cole says.

The problem is a former entrepreneur who was really good at building a trucking company doesn’t know how to manage a $200 million fortune, and the resulting investment decisions, and family decisions, that it requires. “It’s a huge opportunity,” Cole says.

Bank of America Private Bank

Bank of America Private Bank’s growth is evident in the expectation it will have 600 financial advisors by the end of next year, double the number it had in 2014. Perhaps more significantly, the client-facing teams working with those advisors—portfolio managers, trust officers, credit specialists—has grown 15% in the last year-and-a-half, says Katy Knox, president of the private bank, which was known as U.S. Trust until a February name change.

“What we really tried to do is support the entire team and add resources,” Knox says.

The private bank also is seeking growth within the 90 U.S. markets already served by its parent. From a presence in about 33 markets today, the bank plans to be in 40 of the top 50 by the end of 2019. This will allow it to better build on relationships the bank already has with customers who may be a natural fit with the private bank. Knox notes that bank’s internal referrals are up 55% from a year ago.

“If you work with your partners in the consumer bank, small business, business banking, commercial banking, and investment banking—you don’t really have to leave the building to get a new client, you just have to be a great partner,” Knox says.

U.S. Bank’s Boutique Strategy in Ascent

U.S. Bank’s Ascent Private Capital Management, only eight years old, focuses solely on ultra-wealthy families with at least US$75 million in net worth. The boutique unit functions more like a multi-family office, providing services like legacy planning and family governance, what the firm likes to call wealth sustainability—“all the stuff that goes along with keeping the family together,” says John Zimmerman, Ascent’s president.

That focus on family legacy is the core of Ascent’s approach to the extent that half of the group’s clients don’t even hold assets with the firm. Instead, Zimmerman says, “we approach a family with a holistic and integrated approach to managing what may, in many cases, be a business enterprise into their family enterprise.”

The challenge for wealth managers who want to serve this market won’t be delivering a few percentage points more return to their client’s investments he argues, it’s “how do we stay coincident with, or ahead of, the demands of our clients,” he says.

Among shifts in the landscape are changing definitions of families, longer-living matriarchs and patriarchs, and the rising influence of younger generations on how a family deploys its wealth.

“Typically, it was the wealth creators pushing their values down,” Zimmerman says. “Now we’re seeing millennials effect change up.”
description: To capture a profitable sector, banks are focusing more on services that keep families intact
